Award.AwardTitle: Linking elastic and electrical properties to investigate partial melting in the deep mantle
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Alisha Clark has been granted an NSF EAR Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out research and education plans at Northwestern University and Scripps Institute of Oceanography at University of California, San Diego. The project will focus on conducting laboratory experiments to determine velocity and electrical properties of silicate melts of basaltic composition at high pressure and temperature conditions. Silicate melts are the most efficient means of transporting heat and mass and have played a critical role in planetary differentiation. Experimental data at pressure and temperatures corresponding to the observed geophysical anomalies are required to interpret the physical state of the Earth's interior. This interdisciplinary research project spans topics in mineral physics, petrology, solid-Earth geophysics, materials science, and condensed matter physics. Dr. Clark will be engaged in Project Excite at Northwestern University that aims increasing enrollment of underrepresented minority students in Evanston Township High School's honors science and mathematics courses. In addition, she will mentor undergraduate students in research related to this project.

This investigation will provide information on both elastic and electrical properties of basaltic melts at high pressures and temperatures to produce an equation of state for silicate melts at pressures up to the
Earth's transition zone, 410-660 km. To accomplish these goals, Dr. Clark will use the latest generation Gigahertz-ultrasonic interferometer at Northwestern University to constrain the acoustic velocities and elastic moduli at high pressure and temperatures. In addition, the principal investigator will use the new multi-anvil system at Scripps to perform electrical conductivity measurements on the same silicate melts at high pressures and temperatures and correlate these trends with velocity, as well as to determine the effect of melt fraction of electrical conductivity. The last component of the investigation will consist of determining the influence of volatiles on basaltic melt velocity and conductivity. The results from this investigation will be important when interpreting geophysical observations and will provide constrains on the physical properties of silicate melts at depths greater tan 410 km.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Regions in the Earth that have anomalously low seismic velocities or high electrical conductivities relative to average Earth properties at the same depth are commonly thought to correspond to the presence of silicate melts. Some of the regions that are thought to have partial melt present are at the lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary, below spreading ridges and volcanic centers (including hotspots), and at the upper and lower boundaries of the mantle transitions zone (from 410-660 km depth).

Interpreting the volume, spatial distribution, and composition of silicate melts within the Earth from geophysical observables such as seismic data requires experimental constraints. Measuring the physical properties of silicate melts at high pressures and temperature corresponding to the conditions in the Earth to understand 1) where silicate melts are in the present-day Earth and 2) better understand the role of melts in the dynamic evolution of our planet was the focus of this project.

Amorphous silicates - glasses and melts, which lack the long-range periodic arrangement of atoms found in crystalline materials - behave counter to the intuition built by observing the high-pressure behavior of crystalline silicates. Crystalline silicates have a well-establish colinear relationship between density/pressure and seismic velocity. As density is increase in a mineral, the seismic velocity increases because stiffness of the bonds between atoms increases (i.e. effectively compressing the spring between atoms in the harmonic oscillator approximation of atomic bonding). This means that the physical properties of crystalline materials at extreme conditions can be predicted accurately using equations of state. However, amorphous silicates lack the colinear relationship between density and seismic velocity observed in crystalline materials as well as other density-property relationships, making their high-pressure properties unknown without experimental constraints.

During the course of this project, technical development of both GHz-frequency ultrasonic interferometry and electrical conductivity methods expanded the pressure and temperature ranges for measuring the velocity and electrical conductivities of amorphous materials to pressure corresponding to the mantle transition zone. Science goals of developing an atomic understanding of how amorphous materials densify and how the atomic rearrangements can affect geophysical observable were explored. The PI received postdoctoral mentorship throughout the academic hiring process and has begun a tenure-track position at the University of Colorado Boulder in the Department of Geosciences beginning Fall 2019. The PI has successfully recruited a graduate student to join her at CU Boulder establishing her research program and research group focusing on matter at extreme conditions and the evolution of planetary interiors. The PI has also been awarded a Z-Fundamental Science Program award through Sandia National Laboratories. This collaboration is expanding the pressures and temperatures range measuring the properties of silicate liquids in planetary interiors by more than an order of magnitude. This research is ongoing and is focused on understanding if silicate liquids formed deep in planetary interiors during major planetary impacts are a possible reservoir for primordial material including serving as a source for the origin of Earth?s water. New research directions are direct outgrowths from and mirror the goals of the research performed in this project and are serving as the basis for the PI?s new research program at CU Boulder.
